Welcome to Fractal Maps!

This app is designed to showcase the relationship between the Mandelbrot set and Julia set fractals.

Move around the fractals with one finger and pinch to zoom. When you zoom, the fractal will re-render with more detail.

Tap and drag on the pin shown on the Mandelbrot fractal, to change the seed used for the associated Julia set, in real-time.

You can change the viewing configuration by long tapping on either fractal, or using the menu at the top-right. Bring a context menu up, and choose one of the options to make the fractal bigger, smaller, or toggle the viewing configuration between side-by-side and large-small.

Fractal Maps works in both portrait and landscape mode - rotate your device to try it out!

Fractal Maps is open-source software, released under the GNU General Public License (v3). The source code can be found at https://github.com/voxelcarrot/FractalMaps.

About fractals

A fractal is a \"self-similar\" shape, meaning that the same detailed pattern repeats over and over again as you zoom in. In the Mandelbrot set fractal, for example, those distinctive heart-shaped bulbs will keep appearing.

Fractals are generated by iterating a mathematical function on a set of points. Doing more iterations takes a longer time but produces more detailed shapes. More iterations have to be done when zooming in, to keep the same level of apparent detail.

About the Mandelbrot and Julia sets

Probably the most recognisable fractal of them all, the Mandelbrot set was discovered and popularised by mathematician Benoit Mandelbrot, who also invented the term \"fractal\" to describe the shapes he studied. It was one of the first fractals to be visualised on a computer, on March 1st, 1980, in IBM\'s Thomas J. Watson Research Centre.

Julia sets are an older idea, first researched in the early 20th century by Gaston Julia. When a Julia set is defined using the same function that defines the Mandelbrot set, some very interesting behaviour appears. If the Julia set is parametirised by a point inside the Mandelbrot set, it will be connected. Moving out of the Mandelbrot set causes the Julia fractal to break apart into unconnected pieces.

The Mandelbrot and Julia sets also look similar in certain regions, particularly on the borders of the Mandelbrot. It is these relationships that Fractal Maps was developed to demonstrate.

Controls

Drag with a single finger to move around the fractals. Any new areas will fill themselves in once you stop.

Use two fingers to zoom in and out. Again, the fractal will re-render once you stop.

Drag around the pin shown on the Mandelbrot set to change the seed used to render the Julia set. If you lose the pin, you can either long tap on the set to bring up the context menu, or use the application menu up top right.

From each fractal\'s context menu (long tap, or choose from the application menu) you can swap the position of the fractals, or view one larger with a preview of the other up top left. You can also rotate your device to use the app in both landscape and portrait.

Other Menu Options

Under Settings, you can choose the colouring scheme for each fractal, the colour of the Julia pin, whether or not to do an initial crude rendering (a blockier first pass that gives a faster first impression but takes slightly longer overall), and whether or not to show the time for each render after it\'s complete.
